hero.title: Activists Keep Disappearing in Marcos’s Philippines
hero.description: Military kidnappings have produced a public outcry.

primary.lead: Second Chinese Water Cannon Incident on Resupply Ships
primary.title: How a Decaying Warship Beached on a Tiny Shoal Provoked China’s Ire
primary.description: After multiple maritime clashes, the Philippines invited journalists on a mission to resupply the Sierra Madre. A reporter for The Times was given rare access.

secondary.title: China blasts Philippine vessel anew with water cannon
secondary.description: China Coast Guard and militia vessels again used water cannons and made dangerous maneuvers in an attempt yesterday to block a Philippine resupply mission for troops stationed on the BRP Sierra Madre in Ayungin (Second Thomas) Shoal.

secondary.title: The Philippine government has accused a China Coast Guard (CCG) vessel of firing a water cannon at a Philippine boat on a resupply mission to Ayungin Shoal on Friday morning.
secondary.description: Water cannon used anew on supply boat

secondary.title: 5 versus 11: PH makes it past China’s blocking tactics and into Ayungin Shoal
secondary.description: While only 11 Chinese ships conducted ‘dangerous maneuvers’ and actively tried to block five Philippine ships en route to Ayungin Shoal on a resupply mission to the BRP Sierra Madre, over 38 Chinese ships – from their coast guard, maritime militia, and even their navy – were monitored in the area

carousel.title: 10 years after Yolanda, Tacloban rises from the ruins
carousel.description: As the Philippines prepares to commemorate the 10th anniversary of Haiyan, Mayor Alfred Romualdez said survivors had 'moved on' from the disaster.

carousel.title: Fully jabbed kids in PH on a decline
carousel.description: The Department of Health (DOH) on Friday, November 10, 2023, sounded the alarm over the stark decline in the number of fully immunized children (FIC) over the past three years

carousel.title: Philippine Journalist Shot Dead Live on Air
carousel.description: The murder was brazen and swift: two men entered the home of Juan Jumalon in the town of Calamba in the southern Philippines while the radio journalist was broadcasting live on his on Sunday morning show on 94.7 Gold FM.

carousel.title: Unemployment rate rose to 4.5% driven by inflation, interest rates - Manila Standard
carousel.description: The country’s unemployment rate in September 2023 slightly increased to 4.5 percent from 4.4 percent a month ago, partly driven by elevated inflation and higher interest rates, data from the Philippine Statistics Authority (PSA) showed.
